body:
from the definition in https://easings.net/#easeInExpo
we're missing a `if t == 0.0 { return 0.0;}`

To be precise the formula should be something like:
```
(exp(at) - 1) / (exp(a) - 1)
```
where a is whatever parameter you like
What happened was a bunch of approximations:
```
// choose a to be some "large" number, like 10
(exp(at) - 1) / (exp(a) - 1)
// exp(a) >> 1, so the -1 got neglected
(exp(at) - 1) / exp(a)
exp(at - a) - exp(-a)
// exp(-a) is very small, so it got neglected as well
exp(at - a)
// finally in this case a = 10 ln(2), so we get
2^(10t - 10)
```
For t = 1 the two approximations cancelled out, for t = 0, the second approximation introduced the error.

Personally not a huge fan of the special case for t = 0.0, seems to me like it just shunts the issue to the next floating point number.

Agreed, fixing 0 doesn't solve the problem because it just moves the jump to 1.17549435e-38_f32 instead -- the whole range [0, 0.000983241] is wrong since in that range `expIn(x) â‰¥ x`, which should never be the case since it's supposed to be concave-up.

Shame that this is a problem in upstream too :/

Well, upstream isn't really a problem; we own `EaseFunction`, so we can do whatever we deem best. Personally, I think just ditching some of the approximations is probably fine, but I also don't feel strongly about this (other than it certainly should produce zero at `t = 0.0`).

My proposal would be to just use the formula I posted earlier, it effectively incurs a cost of one division and one subtraction (as opposed to one branch), which is imo negligible. The code is a bit uglier, but it would at least (with a proper doc comment) explain how you can adapt the code for other parameters than `10 ln(2)`
there's no really "upstream" or "standard" here, the page I linked (and used when creating the functions) is what people coming from the web are used to
Yeah, I don't think web people will notice us using a slightly different function (the difference is on the order of thousands), it will still have the exponential shape and feel.

And add a bunch of tests to show that all the monotonic easing functions have roughly the expected shape.

# Objective

The `EaseFunction::Exponential*` variants aren't actually smooth as currently implemented, because they jump by about 1â€° at the start/end/both.  

- Fixes #16676
- Subsumes #16675

## Solution

This PR slightly tweaks the shifting and scaling of all three variants to ensure they hit (0, 0) and (1, 1) exactly while gradually transitioning between them.

Graph demonstration of the new easing function definitions: <https://www.desmos.com/calculator/qoc5raus2z>
![desmos-graph](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/c87e9fe5-47d9-4407-9c94-80135eef5908)
(Yes, they look completely identical to the previous ones at that scale.  [Here's a zoomed-in comparison](https://www.desmos.com/calculator/ken6nk89of) between the old and the new if you prefer.)

The approach taken was to keep the core 2Â¹â°áµ— shape, but to [ask WolframAlpha](https://www.wolframalpha.com/input?i=solve+over+the+reals%3A+pow%282%2C+10-A%29+-+pow%282%2C+-A%29%3D+1) what scaling factor to use such that f(1)-f(0)=1, then shift the curve down so that goes from zero to one instead of Â¹/â‚â‚€â‚‚â‚ƒ to Â¹â°Â²â´/â‚â‚€â‚‚â‚ƒ.

## Testing

I've included in this PR a bunch of general tests for all monotonic easing functions to ensure they hit (0, 0) to (1, 1), that the InOut functions hit (Â½, Â½), and that they have the expected convexity.

You can also see by inspection that the difference is small.  The change for `exponential_in` is from `exp2(10 * t - 10)` to `exp2(10 * t - 9.99859â€¦) - 0.0009775171â€¦`.

The problem for `exponential_in(0)` is also simple to see without a calculator: 2â»Â¹â° is obviously not zero, but with the new definition `exp2(-LOG2_1023) - FRAC_1_1023` => `1/(exp2(LOG2_1023)) - FRAC_1_1023` => `FRAC_1_1023 - FRAC_1_1023` => `0`.


---

## Migration Guide

This release of bevy slightly tweaked the definitions of `EaseFunction::ExponentialIn`, `EaseFunction::ExponentialOut`, and `EaseFunction::ExponentialInOut`.  The previous definitions had small discontinuities, while the new ones are slightly rescaled to be continuous.  For the output values that changed, that change was less than 0.001, so visually you might not even notice the difference.

However, if you depended on them for determinism, you'll need to define your own curves with the previous definitions.

body:
I found a way to do this that adds at most a single addition, by pulling the scale factor into the exponent: PR #16910

TL/DR: instead of `exp2(10 * t - 10)`, `exp2(10 * t - 9.99859â€¦) - 0.0009775â€¦`.

> Very ugly, but completely valid.

Yeah, I'd prefer to write it out in the mathmatically-clearer way and let the compiler optimize it, but we don't have a way to do that yet (especially with `cfg(feature = "libm")`) so for now it's probably better to `exp2(x - 11)` instead of `exp2(x - 10) / 2`.
